## The Model Framework
#### Adsorption & Residence Time

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column}
![](../imgs/adsorption.png){height=380}

* from @Teolis2023
* particles are thermally (first order) adsorbed to the surface
  - residence time as statistical time-scale for desorption: $\qquad\residenceTime = \frac{\PlanckConstant}{\BoltzmannConstant\temperature}\cdot\exp\left(\frac{\energy}{\GasConstant\temperature}\right)$
* physisorption requires less energy than chemisorption
:::

::: {.column}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
![](../imgs/residence_time.png)
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* $\energy_{\ce{H}} = \energy_{\ce{H2}} = 0$  [@Hodges1973]
* $\energy_{\ce{OH}, min} = 6.75 \times 10^{4} \si{\joule\per\mole}$, $\energy_{\ce{OH}, max} = 11.58 \times 10^{4} \si{\joule\per\mole}$ 
* $\energy_{\ce{H2O}, min} = 6.08 \times 10^{4} \si{\joule\per\mole}$, $\energy_{\ce{H2O}, max} = 8.68 \times 10^{4} \si{\joule\per\mole}$ 
* see @Grumpe2019, @Sarantos2020, @Reiss2018
:::
:::

## The Model Framework
#### Conversions

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width=40%}

</br>

* Multi-element simulation: $\ce{H}$, $\ce{H2}$, $\ce{OH}$, and $\ce{H2O}$
* Assumption: Surface-bounded exosphere with particles **not** interacting with each other
  - Dependencies between particles solely through **conversion reactions**
* Conversions can take place in the exosphere and on the surface
  - exosphere: photodissociation of hydrogen-based molecules
  - surface: physical/chemical reactions with the regolith and other volatiles
:::

::: {.column width=20%}
:::

::: {.column width=40%}

## The Model Framework  {auto-animate=true}
#### Conversions -- Photoionization and -dissociation

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width=45%}
Rates by @Huebner1992

</br></br>

* [Ionization]{.fragment .highlight-current-blue  fragment-index=1} removes particles from the simulation
* [Dissociation]{.fragment .highlight-current-blue  fragment-index=2} converts particles into other exospheric species

</br></br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
::: {.callout-note appearance="minimal" icon=false}
# Photoreactions of Adsorbate Species
The same base rates were used for the photoreactions of absorbed species, scaled with the cosine of the solar zenith angle:
$$ \rate_{ads} = \begin{cases}\cos \zenithAngle \cdot \rate & \text{for: } \zenithAngle \leq \pi/2 \\ 0 & \text{else.}\end{cases}$$
:::

## The Model Framework  {auto-animate=true}
#### Conversions -- Surface Reactions

![](../imgs/crider2002.png){.shadowbox}

</br>

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column}
* probabilities reported in @Crider2002

* assumption: the same probabilities are valid for neutral $\ce{H}$, leading to
  - $\ce{H ->[60\%] H2}$[: recombinative desorption of $\ce{H}$ & $\ce{OH}$]{.fragment fragment-index=1}
  - $\ce{H ->[10\%] OH}$[: proton implantation and atomic hydrogen diffusion]{.fragment fragment-index=1}
  - $\ce{H ->[2\%] H2O}$[: recombinative desorption of $\ce{OH}$]{.fragment fragment-index=1}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* water reaction requires protons to first convert to hydroxyl, which happens at a 10% chance: $\ce{OH ->[16\%] H2O}$
:::

:::
::: {.column}

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
* note that these probabilities are **global** values (no temperature/time/concentration/etc. dependence), with the authors highlighting their high uncertainties
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4}
* assumption: the ratio between the reported likelihoods is able to represent the proton/hydrogen interaction with the lunar surface at $60:10:2$
* reactivity fraction $\xi$ is scaling these probabilities up/down
:::

:::
::::
